content.title: Theoretical Minimum Temperature (Absolute Zero)
content.abstract: Absolute zero (0 K) is the theoretical minimum temperature, representing the state of minimum possible entropy. The Third Law of Thermodynamics states it cannot be reached in finite steps, but can be approached arbitrarily closely.

third_law_of_thermodynamics.nernst_statement: The entropy of a perfect crystal approaches zero as T → 0
third_law_of_thermodynamics.unattainability: It is impossible to reach absolute zero in a finite number of operations
third_law_of_thermodynamics.mathematical: As T → 0, ΔS → 0, making further cooling exponentially difficult

what_happens_at_absolute_zero.ground_state: System is in lowest quantum energy state
what_happens_at_absolute_zero.entropy: S = k_B ln(Ω) = 0 for non-degenerate ground state

approaches_to_absolute_zero.mechanism: Entropy reduction via magnetic field removal

quantum_limits.zero_point_energy: Even at T = 0, E = ℏω/2 per mode
quantum_limits.helium_superfluidity: Helium remains liquid at T → 0 (zero-point motion too large)
quantum_limits.quantum_phase_transitions: Phase transitions can occur at T = 0 driven by quantum fluctuations

negative_temperatures.possibility: Yes, in systems with bounded energy spectrum
negative_temperatures.not_below_zero: Negative T is HOTTER than any positive T, not colder

planck_temperature_is_maximum.meaning: Temperature where quantum gravity effects dominate
planck_temperature_is_maximum.not_minimum: Planck temperature is a MAXIMUM, not a minimum!
planck_temperature_is_maximum.occurs_at: Very early universe (~Planck time), black hole evaporation end

comparison_planck_vs_absolute_zero.range: Temperature spans 32 orders of magnitude from accessible to Planck
